<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Three new MOFs comprising one mixed-donor ligand (5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI) are synthesized and structurally characterized. <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> features 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels and it performs (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> shows a 2D rarely sandwich-like tri-layer, and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. The fluorescence properties of these three new MOFs were measured at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Three new MOFs comprising one mixed-donor ligand (5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid, H3TZI) are synthesized and structurally characterized. JUC-165 features 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels and it performs (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 shows a 2D rarely sandwich-like tri-layer, and JUC-167 exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. The fluorescence properties of these three new MOFs were measured at room temperature.

Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn2(TZI)(μ 3-OH)(H2O)2]⋅(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ 3-OH)(H2O)7]⋅4H2O (JUC-166), and [Cd(TZI)]⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅H2O (JUC-167) (JUC=Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and a prominent ligand, 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI). JUC-165 exhibits fascinating three-dimensional (3D) structure containing 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2 and it performs (5,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 displays a 2D sandwich-layer which further forms into a 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions and JUC-167 exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm, respectively.

<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The crystal engineering of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have developed at an unusually fast pace in recent years due to their fascinating topologies and various potential applications, such as adsorption, separation, catalysis, fluorescence and magnetic properties . Many factors are known to affect the self-assembly of coordination structures. However, the construction of MOFs is determined primarily by metal centres and organic ligands. Organic ligands acting as bridging linkers between metal centres play a key role in tuning the structural topology and functionality of MOFs when the coordination number and geometry of the metal centres are relatively fixed . Nitrogen containing tetrazole subunits have been utilized to generate a wide diversity of structural motifs ranging from discrete molecular rings to 3D frameworks. Tetrazoles and their derivatives, such as five-membered N-heterocyclic azoles, are prominent of multi-connectivity abilities and high structural stability . For O-donor ligands, the outstanding ones of containing <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate subunit are of special interest. It is an intense evidence of an important role on targeting functional MOF materials that many excellent MOFs which constructed by the linkers containing <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate subunit . Meanwhile, it has to be proved that mixing different donors/subunits in one ligand is a wisdom strategy , thus, based on elaboration above mixed <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazole subunits in one ligand will be extraordinary to create ideal materials . From another point of view to achieve structural diversity is the incorporation of linkers with flexibility into the framework. And in common sense the flexible nature of typical flexible or semi-rigid ligands containing such as -CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- spacers or at least one sp<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> hybrid atom (usually C, N, or O) have been noted and mentioned in many researches which allows the ligands to bend and rotate freely when coordinating to metal centers . But it is interesting that so as to conform to the coordination geometries of metal ions, rigid ligands can also perform similar flexible-like features for the twist and tent of different motifs in one linker which will bring on unforeseen various frameworks and functions . The detailed study and discussion about the effects of flexibility in rigid ligands are meaningful.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have developed at an unusually fast pace in recent years due to their fascinating topologies and various potential applications, such as adsorption, separation, catalysis, fluorescence and magnetic properties . Many factors are known to affect the self-assembly of coordination structures. However, the construction of MOFs is determined primarily by metal centres and organic ligands. Organic ligands acting as bridging linkers between metal centres play a key role in tuning the structural topology and functionality of MOFs when the coordination number and geometry of the metal centres are relatively fixed . Nitrogen containing tetrazole subunits have been utilized to generate a wide diversity of structural motifs ranging from discrete molecular rings to 3D frameworks. Tetrazoles and their derivatives, such as five-membered N-heterocyclic azoles, are prominent of multi-connectivity abilities and high structural stability . For O-donor ligands, the outstanding ones of containing m-benzenedicarboxylate subunit are of special interest. It is an intense evidence of an important role on targeting functional MOF materials that many excellent MOFs which constructed by the linkers containing m-benzenedicarboxylate subunit . Meanwhile, it has to be proved that mixing different donors/subunits in one ligand is a wisdom strategy , thus, based on elaboration above mixed m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazole subunits in one ligand will be extraordinary to create ideal materials . From another point of view to achieve structural diversity is the incorporation of linkers with flexibility into the framework. And in common sense the flexible nature of typical flexible or semi-rigid ligands containing such as -CH2- spacers or at least one sp3 hybrid atom (usually C, N, or O) have been noted and mentioned in many researches which allows the ligands to bend and rotate freely when coordinating to metal centers . But it is interesting that so as to conform to the coordination geometries of metal ions, rigid ligands can also perform similar flexible-like features for the twist and tent of different motifs in one linker which will bring on unforeseen various frameworks and functions . The detailed study and discussion about the effects of flexibility in rigid ligands are meaningful.

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TZI)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH (<ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(TZI)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>) as well as [Cd(TZI)]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>) were constructed. It’s notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn2(TZI)(μ 3-OH)(H2O)2]⋅(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ 3-OH)(H2O)7]⋅4H2O (JUC-166) as well as [Cd(TZI)]⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅H2O (JUC-167) were constructed. It's notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H3TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. JUC-165 featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, JUC-167 exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm of JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167, respectively.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and methods

All the chemical reagents in this work were acquired from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 analyzer. The Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a SHIMADZU LabX XRD-6000 diffractometer with Cu-Ka radiation (λ =1.5418Å) at 40kV and 30mA at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA thermogravimetric analyzer under air flow. Fourier-transform infrared spectra were obtained on a Nicolet Impact 410 FT-IR spectrometer by using KBr pellets in the 4000-400cm-1 range. Fluorescent data were obtained using a Cary Eclipse fluorometer at room temperature.

Synthesis of JUC-167 

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.06mmol, 0.02g), H3TZI (0.05mmol, 0.012g), and DMF/EtOH/H2O (4:2:1, 7mL) was adjusted to pH about 4.0 with 2M HNO3 and 0.5M NaOH solution. elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure determination and refinement

Diffraction intensities for JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 collected at 293K on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated MoKα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation by using the ω-scan technique. The structures ware solved using the shelxs-97 program and refined anisotropically by a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F2 using shelxl-97 . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and the hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were located by geometrically. And the guest H2O molecule number was determined by elemental analysis and TG analysis. Experimental details for the structural determinations of these complexes are reported in  , while the selected bond length and angle data are presented in .

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Cmcm</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, 0.25 TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, 0.25 <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> and one bridging oxygen atom from a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn–O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] SBU are formed by <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (c). A better insight into the nature of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand coordinated to five [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-165 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-165 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn2+ cations, 0.25 TZI3- ligand, 0.25 μ 3-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH3)2NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI3- ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as μ 6-η1: η0: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 ( a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3- and one bridging oxygen atom from a μ 3-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI3- ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN2O3 coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two μ 3-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI3- ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn-O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)Å, and the Zn-N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn3(μ 3-OH)] SBU are formed by μ 3-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI3- spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by m-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5×3.0Å2) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the c axis (c). A better insight into the nature of JUC-165 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn3(μ 3-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H2O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI3- ligand coordinated to five [Zn3(μ 3-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of JUC-165 is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4664 (d).

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction of <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>. The asymmetric unit contains five Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>anion, one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH and seven terminal coordinated water molecular (). For the TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, three kind of coordination modes were found which can be described as <ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> (type (I)), <ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> (type (II)), and <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> (type (III)), respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a and b). It is worth noting that the dihedral between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 58.8°, 45.5°, and 2.2° of the three modes, respectively (). In this structure, there are five kinds of Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> sites. Among them, Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, Cd5 are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry. For Cd1, it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two terminal coordinated waters and one bridging oxygen <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand, and three nitrogen atoms from three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands. The Cd2 atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands and three nitrogen atoms from three different TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands. Cd3 atom is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from one TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, three terminal coordinated waters and one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand, and one nitrogen atom from one TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand. For Cd5, it is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand. While the Cd4 is seven-coordinated which consist of five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, forming a single-cap triangular prism geometry. The Cd–O bond distances are from 2.267(8) to 2.567(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cd–N bond distances are 2.346(8) and 2.457(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). The type (I) and type (II) linkers connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers to form two different 2D layers which are in the top and bottom, respectively. The two layers are like twins for they are very similar which form to a double-layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2 centers (c). In addition, the type (III) linkers as well as <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd3 and Cd4 centers to form another layer in the middle (d). And the intermediate layer is like a mirror which is caught in the middle of the twins-like layers (). Thus, the three monolayers form an overall sandwich-like 2D layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers. As we know, the sandwich-like tri-layer structure is rare . There are strong hydrogen bonding interactions (O6W–H⋯O1, O6W–H⋯O3 and O7W–H···O7 distance of 2.9350, 2.9136 and 2.7421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively ()) between adjacent 2D layers. The layers stack each other to form 3D supramolecular frameworks further (e).</ce:para>

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-166 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-166 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121. The asymmetric unit contains five Cd2+ cations, three TZI3-anion, one μ 3-OH and seven terminal coordinated water molecular (). For the TZI3- ligand, three kind of coordination modes were found which can be described as μ5 -η1: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 η0 (type (I)), μ5 -η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η0 (type (II)), and μ 7-η0: η1: η2: η2: η1: η1: η0: η1 (type (III)), respectively ( a and b). It is worth noting that the dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 58.8°, 45.5°, and 2.2° of the three modes, respectively (). In this structure, there are five kinds of Cd2+ sites. Among them, Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, Cd5 are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry. For Cd1, it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two terminal coordinated waters and one bridging oxygen μ 3-OH ligand, and three nitrogen atoms from three TZI3- ligands. The Cd2 atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one μ 3-OH ligands, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3- ligands and three nitrogen atoms from three different TZI3- ligands. Cd3 atom is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from one TZI3- ligand, three terminal coordinated waters and one μ 3-OH ligand, and one nitrogen atom from one TZI3- ligand. For Cd5, it is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of three TZI3-, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3- ligand. While the Cd4 is seven-coordinated which consist of five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TZI3-, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3- ligand, forming a single-cap triangular prism geometry. The Cd-O bond distances are from 2.267(8) to 2.567(7)Å, and the Cd-N bond distances are 2.346(8) and 2.457(7)Å (). The type (I) and type (II) linkers connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers to form two different 2D layers which are in the top and bottom, respectively. The two layers are like twins for they are very similar which form to a double-layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2 centers (c). In addition, the type (III) linkers as well as μ 3-OH ligand connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd3 and Cd4 centers to form another layer in the middle (d). And the intermediate layer is like a mirror which is caught in the middle of the twins-like layers (). Thus, the three monolayers form an overall sandwich-like 2D layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers. As we know, the sandwich-like tri-layer structure is rare . There are strong hydrogen bonding interactions (O6W-H⋯O1, O6W-H⋯O3 and O7W-H⋅⋅⋅O7 distance of 2.9350, 2.9136 and 2.7421Å, respectively ()) between adjacent 2D layers. The layers stack each other to form 3D supramolecular frameworks further (e).

<ce:section-title id="st070">Description of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction of <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, one TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anion, and one (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature () . For the TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, its coordination mode can be described as <ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). The dihedral between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (). So the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate motifs connect metal centers to form chains along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis, and tetrazoly units link Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> to construct chains along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. For metal center, it is five-coordinated with three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, and two nitrogen atoms from other two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, forming a trigonal bipyramidal geometry (b). The Cd–O bond distances are from 2.234(5) to 2.462(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cd–N bond distances are 2.221(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> shows a 3D framework (c). A better insight into the nature of <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (analyzed by the Topos4.0 program) . The TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands and the mental centers could be simplified as 4-connected nodes. After the analysis by the software package TOPOS, the network belongs to a (4,4)-connected bimodal net with point symbol 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8 (d).</ce:para>

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-167 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-167 reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd2+ cations, one TZI3- anion, and one (CH3)2NH2 of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature () . For the TZI3- ligand, its coordination mode can be described as μ4 -η1: η1: η1: η0: η0: η1: η0: η1 ( a). The dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (). So the m-benzenedicarboxylate motifs connect metal centers to form chains along the a axis, and tetrazoly units link Cd2+ to construct chains along c axis. For metal center, it is five-coordinated with three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3-, and two nitrogen atoms from other two TZI3- ligands, forming a trigonal bipyramidal geometry (b). The Cd-O bond distances are from 2.234(5) to 2.462(5)Å, and the Cd-N bond distances are 2.221(6)Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, JUC-167 shows a 3D framework (c). A better insight into the nature of JUC-167 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (analyzed by the Topos4.0 program) . The TZI3- ligands and the mental centers could be simplified as 4-connected nodes. After the analysis by the software package TOPOS, the network belongs to a (4,4)-connected bimodal net with point symbol 42638 (d).

It connects four (<ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>), five (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>), six (<ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>), and seven (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>) metals by different ways in this paper (). In <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, two carboxylate groups bridge two Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> mode, and all of the nitrogen atoms of the tetrazole are involved in coordination connecting four Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions. In <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, three types of TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands show different coordination modes. The type (I) ligand bridges five Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> atoms with one of two carboxylate groups in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> coordination mode, the other one in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> coordination mode, and the tetrazole connects three Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in 1, 2, 3-position. The coordination mode of type (II) ligand is very similar with type (I) ligand except that the two carboxylate groups are all in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> coordination modes. While type (III) ligand connects seven Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> centers with one of two carboxylate groups in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> coordination mode, the other one in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> coordination mode, and the tetrazole connects three Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in 1, 2, 4-position. In <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, four Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> atoms with one of two carboxylate groups in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> coordination mode, and the tetrazole connects two Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in 1, 4-position.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Coordination modes of the ligands

From the structure descriptions above, the mixed-donor ligands can adopt a variety of coordination modes as we expect. It connects four (JUC-167), five (JUC-166), six (JUC-165), and seven (JUC-166) metals by different ways in this paper (). In JUC-165, two carboxylate groups bridge two Zn2+ ions in a μ 1-η1:η0 mode, and all of the nitrogen atoms of the tetrazole are involved in coordination connecting four Zn2+ ions. In JUC-166, three types of TZI3- ligands show different coordination modes. The type (I) ligand bridges five Cd2+ atoms with one of two carboxylate groups in a μ 1-η1:η0 coordination mode, the other one in a μ 1-η1:η1 coordination mode, and the tetrazole connects three Cd2+ ions in 1, 2, 3-position. The coordination mode of type (II) ligand is very similar with type (I) ligand except that the two carboxylate groups are all in μ 1-η1:η1 coordination modes. While type (III) ligand connects seven Cd2+ centers with one of two carboxylate groups in a μ 1-η1:η0 coordination mode, the other one in a μ 3-η2:η2 coordination mode, and the tetrazole connects three Cd2+ ions in 1, 2, 4-position. In JUC-167, four Cd2+ atoms with one of two carboxylate groups in a μ 1-η1:η0 coordination mode, the other one in a μ 1-η1:η1 coordination mode, and the tetrazole connects two Cd2+ ions in 1, 4-position.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st080">Flexible effects of the ligands on the frameworks</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI can be regarded as a partially flexible ligand, where the carboxylate group and the tetrazole/phenl ring can twist and bend freely. In theory, for H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI, there are two ultimate conformations (), the planar conformation (mode-a) and the non-planar conformation (mode-b) with the maximum torsion angle achieves to 90.0° of the two parts belong to the ligand. From the structure descriptions above, it exhibits mode-a conformation with the maximum torsion angle of 90.0° in <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>. However, two conformations are found in <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, one is the approximative mode-a conformation with torsion angle of just 2.2°, and the other is mode-b conformation with torsion angle of 58.8°and 45.5°. And it is notable that the carboxyl gropes of the three types of linkers twist different angles around the benzene ring in this structure, and even the C–C bond which connect benzene and tetrazolyl rings bent 9.8° and 10.9° respect to the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate plane in type (I) as well as type (II) linkers, respectively (). Thus, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI performs remarkable flexibility in the framework. In <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, the dihedral between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (mode-b). Obviously, the outstanding flexible effects of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI meet the complex of the various frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Flexible effects of the ligands on the frameworks

The H3TZI can be regarded as a partially flexible ligand, where the carboxylate group and the tetrazole/phenl ring can twist and bend freely. In theory, for H3TZI, there are two ultimate conformations (), the planar conformation (mode-a) and the non-planar conformation (mode-b) with the maximum torsion angle achieves to 90.0° of the two parts belong to the ligand. From the structure descriptions above, it exhibits mode-a conformation with the maximum torsion angle of 90.0° in JUC-165. However, two conformations are found in JUC-166, one is the approximative mode-a conformation with torsion angle of just 2.2°, and the other is mode-b conformation with torsion angle of 58.8°and 45.5°. And it is notable that the carboxyl gropes of the three types of linkers twist different angles around the benzene ring in this structure, and even the C-C bond which connect benzene and tetrazolyl rings bent 9.8° and 10.9° respect to the m-benzenedicarboxylate plane in type (I) as well as type (II) linkers, respectively (). Thus, H3TZI performs remarkable flexibility in the framework. In JUC-167, the dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (mode-b). Obviously, the outstanding flexible effects of H3TZI meet the complex of the various frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st085">Thermal analysis and PXRD results</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Thermal stabilities of three new MOFs materials have been measured (). For <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, it is found that there was a weight loss of 8.94% before 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponds to the departure of guest (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules (calculated: 9.23%), and the temperature range of 100–280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of the coordinated waters (experimental: 9.31%; calculated: 7.83%), and then the structure decomposed gradually. The residue was 34.73 % corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calculated: 35.38%). For <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 12.91% corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calculated: 13.56%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 45.08%; calculated: 43.93%). For <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 9.41% corresponding to the departure of guest (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH molecules is observed from 50 to 152<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calculated: 11.07%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 33.24%; calculated: 31.58%). The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in . The peak positions of the measured PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the simulated patterns.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis and PXRD results

Thermal stabilities of three new MOFs materials have been measured (). For JUC-165, it is found that there was a weight loss of 8.94% before 110°C, which corresponds to the departure of guest (CH3)2NH2 molecules (calculated: 9.23%), and the temperature range of 100-280°C can be attributed to the removal of the coordinated waters (experimental: 9.31%; calculated: 7.83%), and then the structure decomposed gradually. The residue was 34.73 % corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calculated: 35.38%). For JUC-166, the weight loss of 12.91% corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 252°C (calculated: 13.56%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 45.08%; calculated: 43.93%). For JUC-167, the weight loss of 9.41% corresponding to the departure of guest (CH3)2NH molecules is observed from 50 to 152°C (calculated: 11.07%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 33.24%; calculated: 31.58%). The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in . The peak positions of the measured PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the simulated patterns.

<ce:section-title id="st090">Luminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Luminescent properties of MOFs containing d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal centers have attracted intense interest due to their potential applications, such as in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent display, and so on . In this work, the solid-state photoluminescent spectra of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI ligand, <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> have been carried out at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The main emission peak of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI is at 377<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>326<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which can be attributed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π or π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n transitions. On complexation of the ligands with Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> atom, the emission peaks occur at 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>372<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, 437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>. The Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration . So the emissions of these compounds are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. However, for the three complexes, the main emission peak is highly red-shifted by 33, 60 and 38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, relative to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI ligand. It is known that the replacement of the hydrogen proton by Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions decreases the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π or π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n gap of the carboxylate ligands, resulting in a red shift of the emission peaks . So the emission can be assigned to the chelation of the ligands to the central metals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

Luminescent properties of MOFs containing d10 metal centers have attracted intense interest due to their potential applications, such as in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent display, and so on . In this work, the solid-state photoluminescent spectra of H3TZI ligand, JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 have been carried out at room temperature ( ). The main emission peak of H3TZI is at 377nm (λex  =326nm), which can be attributed to the π∗ →π or π∗ →n transitions. On complexation of the ligands with Zn2+ or Cd2+ atom, the emission peaks occur at 410nm (λ ex =372nm) for JUC-165, 437nm (λ ex =337nm) for JUC-166, and 415nm (λ ex =320nm) for JUC-167. The Cd2+ ions and Zn2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d10 configuration . So the emissions of these compounds are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. However, for the three complexes, the main emission peak is highly red-shifted by 33, 60 and 38nm, respectively, relative to the free H3TZI ligand. It is known that the replacement of the hydrogen proton by Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions decreases the π∗ →π or π∗ →n gap of the carboxylate ligands, resulting in a red shift of the emission peaks . So the emission can be assigned to the chelation of the ligands to the central metals.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st095">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In conclusion, we have described three MOFs with the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid ligand (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI). <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> show different 3D frameworks: in <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, infinite strip-shaped chains in which Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH) triangles are interlinked by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands into a 3D structure with the point symbol 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology; in <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, the unique Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions are linked by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands with the point symbol 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8 topology. And <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> performs a 3D supermolecular structure by strong H-bonds containing rarely 2D sandwich-like tri-layer. Meanwhile, we discussed the interesting flexibility features of this rigid ligand in details, the mixed-donor ligand exhibits wonderful characteristics coordinated with mental centers. Moreover, the luminescence of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> indicated that these MOFs materials may be good candidates for functional materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have described three MOFs with the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid ligand (H3TZI). JUC-165 and JUC-167 show different 3D frameworks: in JUC-165, infinite strip-shaped chains in which Zn3(μ 3-OH) triangles are interlinked by TZI3- ligands into a 3D structure with the point symbol 4664 topology; in JUC-167, the unique Cd2+ ions are linked by TZI3- ligands with the point symbol 42638 topology. And JUC-166 performs a 3D supermolecular structure by strong H-bonds containing rarely 2D sandwich-like tri-layer. Meanwhile, we discussed the interesting flexibility features of this rigid ligand in details, the mixed-donor ligand exhibits wonderful characteristics coordinated with mental centers. Moreover, the luminescence of JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 indicated that these MOFs materials may be good candidates for functional materials.

Synthesis of JUC-165 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.08mmol, 0.012g), H3TZI (0.05mol, 0.012g), DMF 4mL, and H2O (4mL) was stayed at 80°C for 48h. Light yellow block crystals were obtained and dried in air (70% yield based on Zn). EA (%) Anal. Calc. for C11H15N5O7Zn2: C, 28.72; H, 3.29; N, 15.22. Found: C, 28.81; H, 3.16; N, 15.28%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet cm-1): 3420 (br), 3079 (s), 2930 (m), 2868 (m), 1663 (s), 1626 (s), 1593 (s), 1558 (s), 1506 (s), 1448 (s), 1437 (s),1387 (vs), 1256 (w), 1194 (s), 1097(s), 930 (m), 895 (m), 777 (s), 758 (m), 725 (s), 667 (s), 583 (m), 548 (m).

Synthesis of JUC-166 

A mixture of CdCl2⋅2.5H2O (0.14mmol, 0.032g), H3TZI (0.05mmol, 0.012g) and H2O (8mL) was adjusted to pH about 4.0 with 0.05M NaOH solution. It was then sealed in a 25mL Teflon reactor and heated at 150°C for 72h. Finally, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and colorless block-shaped crystals were obtained by filtration. The crystals were washed with distilled water and dried in the air. (yield: 51% based on Cd). EA (%) Anal. Calc. for C27H23N12O24Cd5: C, 22.17; H, 1.59; N, 11.49. Found: C, 22.23; H, 1.41; N, 11.35%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3449 (w), 3069 (w), 1618 (m), 1560 (m), 1501 (s), 1449 (s), 1381 (s), 1244 (m), 1192 (m), 1107 (m), 935 (s), 785 (m), 733 (s), 480 (w).

Synthesis of JUC-167 

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.06mmol, 0.02g), H3TZI (0.05mmol, 0.012g), and DMF/EtOH/H2O (4:2:1, 7mL) was adjusted to pH about 4.0 with 2M HNO3 and 0.5M NaOH solution. It was then sealed in a 25mL Teflon reactor and heated at 120°C for 72h. Finally, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and colorless needle crystals were obtained by filtration. The crystals were washed with DMF and dried in the air. (yield: 55% based on Cd). EA (%) Anal. Calc. for C11H12N5O5Cd: C, 32.49; H, 2.98; N, 17.22. Found: C, 32.87; H, 2.74; N, 17.73%. </ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Three new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TZI)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH (<ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(TZI)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>), and [Cd(TZI)]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>) (JUC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>/Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and a prominent ligand, 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI). <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> exhibits fascinating three-dimensional (3D) structure containing 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and it performs (5,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> displays a 2D sandwich-layer which further forms into a 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TZI)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH (<ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(TZI)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>) as well as [Cd(TZI)]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>) were constructed. It’s notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Description of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Cmcm</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, 0.25 TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, 0.25 <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> and one bridging oxygen atom from a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn–O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] SBU are formed by <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (c). A better insight into the nature of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand coordinated to five [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> (d).</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn2(TZI)(μ 3-OH)(H2O)2]⋅(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ 3-OH)(H2O)7]⋅4H2O (JUC-166), and [Cd(TZI)]⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅H2O (JUC-167) (JUC=Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and a prominent ligand, 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI). JUC-165 exhibits fascinating three-dimensional (3D) structure containing 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2 and it performs (5,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 displays a 2D sandwich-layer which further forms into a 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions and JUC-167 exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm, respectively.

Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn2(TZI)(μ 3-OH)(H2O)2]⋅(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ 3-OH)(H2O)7]⋅4H2O (JUC-166) as well as [Cd(TZI)]⋅(CH3)2NH2⋅H2O (JUC-167) were constructed. It's notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H3TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. JUC-165 featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, JUC-167 exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm of JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167, respectively.

Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-165 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-165 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn2+ cations, 0.25 TZI3- ligand, 0.25 μ 3-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH3)2NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI3- ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as μ 6-η1: η0: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 ( a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3- and one bridging oxygen atom from a μ 3-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI3- ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN2O3 coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two μ 3-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI3- ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn-O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)Å, and the Zn-N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn3(μ 3-OH)] SBU are formed by μ 3-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI3- spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by m-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5×3.0Å2) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the c axis (c). A better insight into the nature of JUC-165 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn3(μ 3-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H2O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI3- ligand coordinated to five [Zn3(μ 3-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of JUC-165 is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4664 (d).

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-166 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-166 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121. The asymmetric unit contains five Cd2+ cations, three TZI3-anion, one μ 3-OH and seven terminal coordinated water molecular (). For the TZI3- ligand, three kind of coordination modes were found which can be described as μ5 -η1: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 η0 (type (I)), μ5 -η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η0 (type (II)), and μ 7-η0: η1: η2: η2: η1: η1: η0: η1 (type (III)), respectively ( a and b). It is worth noting that the dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 58.8°, 45.5°, and 2.2° of the three modes, respectively (). In this structure, there are five kinds of Cd2+ sites. Among them, Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, Cd5 are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry. For Cd1, it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two terminal coordinated waters and one bridging oxygen μ 3-OH ligand, and three nitrogen atoms from three TZI3- ligands. The Cd2 atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one μ 3-OH ligands, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3- ligands and three nitrogen atoms from three different TZI3- ligands. Cd3 atom is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from one TZI3- ligand, three terminal coordinated waters and one μ 3-OH ligand, and one nitrogen atom from one TZI3- ligand. For Cd5, it is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of three TZI3-, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3- ligand. While the Cd4 is seven-coordinated which consist of five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TZI3-, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3- ligand, forming a single-cap triangular prism geometry. The Cd-O bond distances are from 2.267(8) to 2.567(7)Å, and the Cd-N bond distances are 2.346(8) and 2.457(7)Å (). The type (I) and type (II) linkers connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers to form two different 2D layers which are in the top and bottom, respectively. The two layers are like twins for they are very similar which form to a double-layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2 centers (c). In addition, the type (III) linkers as well as μ 3-OH ligand connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd3 and Cd4 centers to form another layer in the middle (d). And the intermediate layer is like a mirror which is caught in the middle of the twins-like layers (). Thus, the three monolayers form an overall sandwich-like 2D layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers. As we know, the sandwich-like tri-layer structure is rare . There are strong hydrogen bonding interactions (O6W-H⋯O1, O6W-H⋯O3 and O7W-H⋅⋅⋅O7 distance of 2.9350, 2.9136 and 2.7421Å, respectively ()) between adjacent 2D layers. The layers stack each other to form 3D supramolecular frameworks further (e).

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-167 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-167 reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd2+ cations, one TZI3- anion, and one (CH3)2NH2 of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature () . For the TZI3- ligand, its coordination mode can be described as μ4 -η1: η1: η1: η0: η0: η1: η0: η1 ( a). The dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (). So the m-benzenedicarboxylate motifs connect metal centers to form chains along the a axis, and tetrazoly units link Cd2+ to construct chains along c axis. For metal center, it is five-coordinated with three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3-, and two nitrogen atoms from other two TZI3- ligands, forming a trigonal bipyramidal geometry (b). The Cd-O bond distances are from 2.234(5) to 2.462(5)Å, and the Cd-N bond distances are 2.221(6)Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, JUC-167 shows a 3D framework (c). A better insight into the nature of JUC-167 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (analyzed by the Topos4.0 program) . The TZI3- ligands and the mental centers could be simplified as 4-connected nodes. After the analysis by the software package TOPOS, the network belongs to a (4,4)-connected bimodal net with point symbol 42638 (d).

Thermal analysis and PXRD results

Thermal stabilities of three new MOFs materials have been measured (). For JUC-165, it is found that there was a weight loss of 8.94% before 110°C, which corresponds to the departure of guest (CH3)2NH2 molecules (calculated: 9.23%), and the temperature range of 100-280°C can be attributed to the removal of the coordinated waters (experimental: 9.31%; calculated: 7.83%), and then the structure decomposed gradually. The residue was 34.73 % corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calculated: 35.38%). For JUC-166, the weight loss of 12.91% corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 252°C (calculated: 13.56%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 45.08%; calculated: 43.93%). For JUC-167, the weight loss of 9.41% corresponding to the departure of guest (CH3)2NH molecules is observed from 50 to 152°C (calculated: 11.07%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 33.24%; calculated: 31.58%). The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in . The peak positions of the measured PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the simulated patterns.

Luminescence properties

Luminescent properties of MOFs containing d10 metal centers have attracted intense interest due to their potential applications, such as in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent display, and so on . In this work, the solid-state photoluminescent spectra of H3TZI ligand, JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 have been carried out at room temperature ( ). The main emission peak of H3TZI is at 377nm (λex  =326nm), which can be attributed to the π∗ →π or π∗ →n transitions. On complexation of the ligands with Zn2+ or Cd2+ atom, the emission peaks occur at 410nm (λ ex =372nm) for JUC-165, 437nm (λ ex =337nm) for JUC-166, and 415nm (λ ex =320nm) for JUC-167. The Cd2+ ions and Zn2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d10 configuration . So the emissions of these compounds are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. However, for the three complexes, the main emission peak is highly red-shifted by 33, 60 and 38nm, respectively, relative to the free H3TZI ligand. It is known that the replacement of the hydrogen proton by Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions decreases the π∗ →π or π∗ →n gap of the carboxylate ligands, resulting in a red shift of the emission peaks . So the emission can be assigned to the chelation of the ligands to the central metals.
